author: mohseng
content: So in case there is widespread outage on the AWS where many people are hosting ETH2, could that trigger a penalty on someone who is not using AWS also, right?  Feels unfair.

author: trent_vanepps
content: i don't think that's the case - in that i don't think there is an explicit penalty. it also depends on what % was using AWS

author: djrtwo
content: if you remain online in such an outage, your balance will remain approximately neutral

author: djrtwo
content: while those offline will begin to leak more and more (as long as not finalizing)

author: mohseng
content: So if less than 1/3 of the validators are offline, everyone gets penalized.  If more than 1/3 are offline, then is the inactivity link case, right?  Danny Ryan says this:

author: mohseng
content: *Inactivity penalty: if the chain isn‚Äôt finalising, penalize everyone, but particularly those who are not participating. Specifically, add a BASE_REWARD_PER_EPOCH * base_reward penalty to each active validator, and add an effective_balance * finality_delay // INACTIVITY_PENALTY_QUOTIENT penalty to each validator that did not vote on the correct target. Note that validators participating optimally during an inactivity leak will not incur any penalties [Potential bug discussed here].*

author: mohseng
content: https://notes.ethereum.org/@djrtwo/Bkn3zpwxB

author: djrtwo
content: that might be worded imperfectly

author: djrtwo
content: if you are doing your job perfectly during a leak, you should remain approximately neutral

author: djrtwo
content: you can't gain here so that can be somewhat a "penalty". at least a call to action to do what is in your power to fix things

author: mohseng
content: OK that makes sense

author: daodesigner
content:
I mean in the extreme outage case, (correct me if I'm wrong) if that epoch happens to have a bunch of slots with empty(ish) beacon committees, the odds of you being selected as a beacon block proposer logically goes up. So you can* gain here technically no? 

Though I guess the down time would need to be significant (#validators*time) for proposer rewards to make any kind of real dent.

author: mohseng
content: AFAIK there's a special penalty for such cases, which is higher and will probably eat up all of your rewards however made

author: djrtwo
content:
you can gain from proposals during a leak
so you can in some cases be profitable

author: djrtwo
content: if you are relatively neutral for performing your attestation duties, then if you are selected for proposal, you can make a little bit of eth

author: mohseng
content: What if we just compensated the good validators after the crisis is over by just issuing eth to them?  too crazy?

author: djrtwo
content: if it was in fact a serious crisis and the leak happened for a long time, the total staking balance would be less and the rewards per staked eth will be higher

author: djrtwo
content: if you reward success too much here, it would incentivize censoring/attacking some subset of validators to induce such a leak to begin with
